name: Framebuffer.bash
tagline: framebuffer in bash to draw ascii pixels, borders, animate e.g. (bash ui bootstrap)
body: # Why Fullfledged html/css/javascript applications are nice, but sometimes a simple email with asciitext does the job. This is for minimalists and productivity fanatics. # Barcharts! will produce something like this: apple : ——▄▄▀▀——▀▀▄▄——▄▄▀▀▄▄——— banana : ▁▁▂▂▃▃▄▄▅▅██▄▄▂▂▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ plum : ██████ orange : ████ apple : ██ foo : ██████████ code example: put 2 3 "stock :"; echo "0,1,2,0,2,1,0,1,2,1" | fb barchart 10 2 20 put 2 7 "banana :"; redis-cli --csv LRANGE foo 0 -1 | sed 's/[^0-9,\\-]*//g' | fb vbarchart 10 6 20 # Number to bar milk 5 ▆▆▆▆▆ cheese 3 ▆▆▆ palinka 14 ▆▆▆▆▆▆▆▆▆▆▆▆▆▆ code example: echo -e "milk 5\ncheese 3\npalinka 14" | fb number2bar 2 # Ascii tables! Get pretty aligned, copy/paste-able output: foo long column 2 foobie bar 5 barrie code example: cat foo.csv | fb csv2ascii cat semicolon.csv | SEP=';' fb csv2ascii CSV's with quoted strings are supported. # Histograms! turns logs into: UFW 1600 █████████████████████████ cfg80211: 11 █████████████ wlan0: 9 █████ ath: 8 █ code example: dmesg | fb histogram 2 25 25 # Animations! code example: fb animate 2 4 0.1 ". o O o" # Boxes! ┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │date: Mon May 19 23:43:45 CEST 2014 │ │ │ └──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘ code example: fb box 1 1 20 10; fb put 2 2 "date: $(date)"
note: Don't delete this file! It's used internally to help with page regeneration.
